pros: McDonald’s is often written off as a deadbeat’s job, but it really isn’t. Employers actually love to see candidates who have worked in McDonald’s, because the job is demanding employers value those with this job experience. Working here shows many positive attributes, such as: resilience, respect, resourcefulness, leadership skills, independence, team-work, and so much more. The value of this job on paper is immeasurable. As a bonus the pay is also great, especially for a student. They also take care of you there, they have many programmes for inclusivity and protection for all minorities (that they do actually take extremely seriously), mental health programmes, weekly offers for a multitude of different stores and brands, amongst a lot more. They value community and the team being familiar and friendly, my store often arranged get togethers outside of work to help with this. McDonald’s is also amazing with scheduling, especially for students, it is completely tailored to what you can and cannot do, the flexibility for students is something you won’t find anywhere else. Students are valued heavily in the workplace, managers take studies seriously and always offer to help push you further in studies and high education interviews, offering to be references and to put in good words. They offer opportunities to students to advance their way up in roles too. Additionally, their attitude towards employees with disabilities is amazing, and they tailor shifts, tasks, and accessibility needs based upon these. I honestly couldn’t think of a better place to work as a student.
cons: The job is stressful, and pretty taxing (though I suppose this could also be seen as a positive, due to the skills and resilience it’ll teach you). McDonald’s is know for being understaffed as well, and when it gets busy, it can be extremely distressing. The stigma, this isn’t a con about the actual tasks of the job, more so what the public assume about employees who work here - it gets tiring hearing people talk down on you because of your job, when in reality having the job is pushing me to a very positive future. I believe the biggest, if not the only, con is how taxing it is and even that can be argued into a pro.

review_title: Great at first, but stinks later!
pros:
Free Meals
Getting Tips
Pay Rate
Working in the Kitchen
Making Customers Happy: Especially when return Customers ask specifically for me to make their special coffees, frappes, & iced coffees.
cons:
Employees and managers will run off and leave one or two employees by themselves on lunch rush. The others will be on break, outside smoking, in the bathroom, in the office talking or anything else they want.

Employees getting left for hours in a position without getting their break or being able to use the restroom. 

Employees getting special treatment while others are treated badly. Ex. An hourly manager takes off on the weekend to go with regular crew members to the beach when she is scheduled to work and no calls no shows. When she comes back, she acts as if she has done nothing wrong. The District Manager is her friend and allows her to do whatever she wants. She is not written up or disciplined in anyway. Neither are the crew members who went with her.

Not being promoted to manager because you don't have a car, yet there are two managers in the store who don't drive. The employee knows all the positions in the store and also has a certificate from a nationally known culinary arts school. The District Manager had to ask this person for help pulling up files from her computer because she didn't know how to do a simple computer task. 

This is a franchise instead of owned by corporate. When it was owned by corporate, the store was better maintained and much much more cleaner! Employees acted more mature and not yelling at customers. Employees weren't getting into fist fights with customers. Employees weren't smoking pot in the stores. The food better and better prepared. Just so much better when this store corporate owned and not owned by greedy, non-caring franchise owners.

review_title: Great until a change in ownership

I would get amazing numbers in terms of getting the line moving, orders out and perfect for each customer, and made each person’s experience the best I possibly could. But I would be told “labor” was too high if I was excelling. Then if I cut back on labor by sending workers home early, I would get admonished for orders taking too long to get out. This only ended up happening when they switched general managers of my store and changed ownership to a new company.

pros:
-some free food/meals
-some great coworkers
-will hire just about anyone (I was a homemaker with an employment gap)
cons:
-Worked to the bone working multiple positions each and every because of short staffing problems and management’s inability to retain employees because of low wage and/or stressful/toxic work environment.
-Always careful to be under 40hrs a week so they don’t have to offer benefits.
-Schedule is all over the place except for senior staff and minors they legally have to accommodate. Don’t expect to get your requested hours or days off often. Changes may occur a day or two before a shift, very hard to plan around.
-Toxic micromanagement who believe being loud/shouting is the best way to get employees motivated/fall in line. Massive source of anxiety as an employee.
-moved up quickly, but more so that existing management could delegate tasks and hours/days they don’t want to deal with anymore. pros: Not quite as bad as you might think. If you’re the type of person who doesn’t get too stressed when there’s a queue leading out the door then you’ll be fine, I was panicking from the minute I clocked in to the minute I clocked out. That was the worst part of the job for me.
cons:
Mentally and physically draining, especially if you’re an anxious person in general because there’s always a queue, and you have to keep taking orders no matter how long the food is taking, and memorise each one until you can bag it and give it to the customer. 

They will always try and get you to do more shifts than you signed up for. I knew this would happen as I’ve done similar jobs before so I lied and said I could only do 2 shifts per week as I had another job baby sitting. I thought that way if they put me down for an extra shift once in a while or asked me to do over time It wouldn’t matter because I was only doing a couple shifts to start with. Anyway it went in one ear and out the other. By week 2 I was doing 5 days and being asked if I could come in on my day off, stay a couple of extra hours etc. And being guilt tripped about how this person did 7 days last week and that person does opening and closing shifts back to back. Basically part time doesn’t exist at this job, and full time means your entire life will be spent at work.
